Front: EC2 instances are virtual servers in the cloud. They differ from physical servers by: being virtualized (can be created/destroyed instantly), scalable (resize capacity), pay-per-use (no upfront costs), no physical maintenance needed, can be replicated easily across regions/AZs.
Back: What are EC2 instances, and how do they differ from traditional physical servers?

Front: EC2 Instance Families: General Purpose (m5, t3) - balanced compute/memory/networking; Compute Optimized (c5) - CPU-intensive; Memory Optimized (r5) - large memory; Storage Optimized (i3) - high IOPS; Accelerated Computing (p3, g4) - GPU/FPGA. Choose based on workload: CPU-bound (Compute), memory-bound (Memory), storage I/O (Storage), ML/graphics (Accelerated).
Back: What are the different EC2 instance type families, and how do you choose the right instance type for a workload?

Front: On-Demand Instances: Pay by hour/second with no commitment. Advantages: flexible, no upfront costs, no long-term commitment. Disadvantages: most expensive pricing model, no discounts. Best for: short-term workloads, unpredictable usage, testing, applications that can't be interrupted.
Back: What are the advantages and disadvantages of On-Demand EC2 instances?

Front: Reserved Instance Types: Standard (up to 75% discount, can't change attributes), Convertible (up to 54% discount, can exchange for different attributes), Scheduled (match capacity to predictable schedules). Use Standard for steady workloads, Convertible for flexibility, Scheduled for predictable schedules.
Back: What are the different Reserved Instance types (Standard, Convertible, Scheduled), and when should each be used?

Front: Spot Instances: Bid for unused EC2 capacity (up to 90% discount). Risks: can be terminated with 2-minute notice when AWS needs capacity. Benefits: very low cost, good for fault-tolerant workloads. Suitable for: batch jobs, data analysis, CI/CD, workloads that can handle interruptions. Not suitable for: databases, critical production apps.
Back: What are the risks and benefits of using EC2 Spot Instances, and what workloads are suitable for them?

Front: Dedicated Hosts: Physical servers dedicated to your use. Choose when: need to use existing server-bound licenses, have compliance requirements, need visibility into socket/core placement. Cost implications: more expensive than regular instances, but can save on licensing costs. Best for: licensing compliance, regulatory requirements.
Back: When would you choose Dedicated Hosts over regular EC2 instances, and what are the cost implications?

Front: EBS (Elastic Block Store): Persistent network-attached storage, survives instance termination, can be detached/reattached. EBS Volume Types: gp3 (general purpose, 3000 IOPS baseline), gp2 (general purpose, 3000 IOPS burst), io1/io2 (provisioned IOPS, up to 64,000 IOPS), st1 (throughput optimized HDD), sc1 (cold HDD). Instance Store: Ephemeral, physically attached, data lost on stop/terminate, very high IOPS.
Back: How does Elastic Block Store (EBS) differ from Instance Store, and what are the EBS volume types?

Front: Instance Store Use Cases: Temporary cache, scratch data, buffer/queue data, temporary files. Advantages: very high IOPS, low latency, free with instance. Disadvantages: data lost on stop/terminate, can't detach/reattach. EBS Use Cases: databases, boot volumes, persistent data, data that needs to survive instance lifecycle.
Back: What are the use cases for Instance Store volumes versus EBS volumes?

Front: Security Groups: Virtual firewalls controlling inbound/outbound traffic to EC2 instances. Characteristics: Stateful (allow inbound automatically allows corresponding outbound response), operate at instance level, default deny all inbound, default allow all outbound, can reference other security groups. Default rules: all inbound denied, all outbound allowed.
Back: How do Security Groups enhance EC2 instance security, and what are the default rules?

Front: EC2 Key Pairs: Public-private key pairs for secure SSH/RDP access. Public key stored by AWS, private key downloaded (must keep secure). Used for: SSH access to Linux instances, RDP access to Windows instances (can use key pair or password). Best practice: don't share private keys, use different key pairs per environment.
Back: What are EC2 Key Pairs, and how do they enable secure access to instances?

Front: Elastic IP Addresses: Static IPv4 addresses for dynamic cloud computing. Purpose: maintain consistent IP when instance stops/starts, remap to different instances quickly. Costs: Free when attached to running instance, charges apply when not attached to any instance or attached to stopped instance. Limit: 5 per region by default.
Back: What is the purpose of Elastic IP Addresses in EC2, and what are the costs associated with them?

Front: User Data: Scripts that run once at instance first launch (boot time) with root privileges. Use cases: install software packages, download files from internet, configure applications, set up web servers, automate system configuration. Runs only on first start, not on subsequent reboots unless configured.
Back: How does User Data work in EC2, and what are common use cases for User Data scripts?

Front: EC2 Instance Metadata: Information about the instance accessible from within the instance. Access via: http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/ (IMDSv1) or use IMDSv2 (token-based, more secure). Includes: instance ID, instance type, public/private IP, security groups, IAM role credentials, placement info. Used for: application configuration, bootstrap scripts, getting instance details programmatically.
Back: What information is available through EC2 Instance Metadata, and how do you access it?

Front: Placement Groups Types: Cluster (low latency, single AZ, risk of simultaneous failure), Spread (maximum isolation, instances on different hardware, multi-AZ, fault tolerance), Partition (rack-level isolation, multiple instances per partition, good for distributed systems). Use Cluster for HPC, Spread for critical apps, Partition for distributed databases.
Back: What are the different EC2 Placement Group types, and when should each be used?

Front: EC2 Auto Scaling: Automatically adjusts number of instances based on demand. Works by: monitoring CloudWatch metrics (CPU, memory, custom), scaling policies (target tracking, step scaling, simple scaling), maintaining desired capacity. Triggers: CPU utilization, network traffic, custom metrics, scheduled actions. Scales out (add instances) when load increases, scales in (remove instances) when load decreases.
Back: How does EC2 Auto Scaling work, and what metrics can trigger scaling events?

Front: Elastic Load Balancing (ELB): Distributes incoming traffic across multiple EC2 instances. Works with Auto Scaling: ELB distributes traffic, Auto Scaling ensures enough instances are running, ELB health checks trigger instance replacement if unhealthy. Benefits: high availability, fault tolerance, automatic failover, improved performance.
Back: Explain the function of Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) and how it works with Auto Scaling.

Front: AMI (Amazon Machine Image): Pre-configured template containing OS, application server, applications. Purpose: quick instance launches, consistent environments, backup/restore, golden images. Create custom AMI: launch instance, configure it, create image from instance (creates snapshot of EBS volumes). Can share AMIs across accounts or publicly.
Back: What is the purpose of an Amazon Machine Image (AMI), and how do you create custom AMIs?

Front: EC2 Instance Lifecycle: pending (launching), running (active), stopping (being stopped), stopped (stopped, billing for storage only), shutting-down (being terminated), terminated (deleted, can't be started). Billing: charged while running, only storage charged when stopped, not charged when terminated. Termination protection prevents accidental termination.
Back: What happens during each stage of the EC2 instance lifecycle, and how does billing work for each state?

Front: CloudWatch EC2 Metrics: CPUUtilization, NetworkIn/Out, DiskReadOps/WriteOps, StatusCheckFailed, custom metrics. Create custom metrics: publish data using PutMetricData API or CloudWatch agent. Use for: application monitoring, business metrics, detailed performance analysis. Metrics stored for 15 months (15 days at 1-minute granularity).
Back: What EC2 metrics are available in CloudWatch, and how can you create custom metrics?

Front: EC2 Instance Connect: Browser-based SSH access without SSH keys. How it works: uses temporary SSH keys generated by AWS, accessed via AWS Console, one-time use. Advantages: no need to manage SSH keys, quick access, secure (temporary credentials), works from anywhere with console access. Limitations: requires IAM permissions, only for emergency access, not for regular use.
Back: How does EC2 Instance Connect work, and what are its advantages over traditional SSH access?

Front: EC2 Hibernate: Preserves in-memory state (RAM) when instance stops. On restart: resumes from exact state (faster than fresh boot). Requirements: instance must support hibernation (certain instance types), root volume must be encrypted, sufficient EBS volume size for RAM. Limitations: not all instance types support it, larger instance families (C5, M5, R5, etc.).
Back: What is EC2 Hibernate, and what are its requirements and limitations?

Front: EC2 Spot Fleet: Manages collection of Spot Instances (and optionally On-Demand) to meet capacity needs. Benefits: automatic diversification across instance types and AZs (reduces interruption risk), cost optimization (chooses cheapest combination), maintains target capacity. Difference from single Spot: higher availability, better fault tolerance, automatic rebalancing.
Back: How does EC2 Spot Fleet differ from individual Spot Instances, and what are its benefits?

Front: Dedicated Instances: Run on hardware dedicated to your account, but you don't control placement. Dedicated Hosts: Physical servers dedicated to you, full control over instance placement, can use existing licenses. Key difference: Dedicated Hosts give you visibility and control over underlying hardware, Dedicated Instances just ensure isolation.
Back: What is the difference between EC2 Dedicated Instances and Dedicated Hosts?

Front: EC2 Launch Templates: Version-controlled templates for instance configurations. Improve upon Launch Configurations by: supporting multiple instance types, versioning (can't modify, must create new version), parameter combinations, better integration with Auto Scaling and Spot Fleet. Launch Configurations are legacy and less flexible.
Back: What are EC2 Launch Templates, and how do they improve upon Launch Configurations?

Front: EC2 Enhanced Networking: Provides higher network performance using SR-IOV (Single Root I/O Virtualization). Benefits: higher bandwidth (up to 100 Gbps), lower latency, lower jitter, more consistent performance. Support: Most current generation instances (C5, M5, R5, etc.) support it. Requires: HVM virtualization, compatible AMI, VPC required.
Back: What is EC2 Enhanced Networking, and which instance types support it?

Front: Instance Store Volumes: Ephemeral storage physically attached to host. Performance: Very high IOPS (hundreds of thousands), very low latency, no network overhead. Use when: need maximum IOPS, temporary/cache data, can afford data loss. Not suitable for: persistent data, databases (unless replicated), anything that needs to survive instance stop.
Back: What are the performance characteristics of Instance Store volumes, and when should they be used?

Front: Termination Protection: Prevents accidental termination of instances. Enable: EC2 Console → Instance → Actions → Instance Settings → Change Termination Protection. Best practices: Enable for production instances, disable for dev/test, use with critical workloads, combine with backups. Note: Still charged when stopped, must disable protection to terminate.
Back: How do you enable termination protection for EC2 instances, and what are best practices?

Front: IMDSv2 (Instance Metadata Service v2): Enhanced metadata service requiring session authentication tokens. Security improvements: Token-based authentication (prevents SSRF attacks), session tokens (time-limited), PUT request required to get token. IMDSv1: Simple GET requests (vulnerable to SSRF). Use IMDSv2 for: better security, compliance requirements, defense in depth. Can enforce IMDSv2 at launch.
Back: What are the security improvements in IMDSv2 compared to IMDSv1, and why should you use it?

Front: EC2 Capacity Reservations: Reserve On-Demand capacity in specific AZ for any duration. Purpose: Ensure capacity is available when needed, guaranteed availability. Difference from Reserved Instances: Capacity Reservations guarantee capacity (not discount), tied to specific AZ, no term commitment, pay On-Demand rates. Reserved Instances provide discounts but don't guarantee capacity.
Back: How do EC2 Capacity Reservations work, and how do they differ from Reserved Instances?

Front: EC2 Instance Naming Pattern: family.generation.size (e.g., t3.micro). Family: indicates use case (t=burstable, m=general purpose, c=compute, r=memory, i=storage). Generation: iteration number (higher = newer/better). Size: resource allocation (nano, micro, small, medium, large, xlarge, 2xlarge, etc.). Example: m5.2xlarge = M family, generation 5, 2xlarge size (8 vCPU, 32 GB RAM).
Back: How do you interpret EC2 instance type names, and what does each component indicate?
